lines: During a college vacation break, you bump into a person who used to be a good friend in high school. He chose to skip college and find a job. He is now working as a machine maintenance engineer at a local plant in your old home
town. When you try to converse with him, he seems distant and aloof, almost resentful.
#MAKE SMALL TALK FOR A FEW MINUTES THEN WALK AWAY
He says, "What would you care? Besides, you have the easy life in college now. You would never understand MY worries."
#ASK HIM IF HE WANTS TO TELL YOU ABOUT IT ANYWAY

The nerve of some people. Besides, who said college was the good life? You chose to walk away from this person's rudeness, which is perfectly O.K.. You couldn't have valued his friendship much or perhaps you would have tried
harder to find out what was behind his hostility.

Your sincerity causes him to see that he has treated you in a rude fashion. He admits that his life is very difficult now. He has bills to pay and other responsibilities he really wasn't ready for. His life is routine and he
gets little enjoyment out of his work.

Seeing you sparked some envy in him, but soon your friendship is renewed. He only criticized you because he felt you might be looking down on him because he didn't go to college--a move he regrets now. Your patience brings down his
defenses and motivates him to take a closer look at his life.

The conversation between you and your friend is stilted and uneasy. You sense a great tension between the two of you. Soon you get the feeling that he is just waiting for you to say something that sounds like you were smart for going to
college, and that he was stupid for getting a job.
